loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of beauty products for her salon

loans.name: Miriam Yanina

texts.es:
Miriam es socia del Banco Comunal Prosperidad.

Miriam es casada, tiene 34 años y 2 hijos, Miriam tiene una tienda en su casa ubicada en el barrio de Quinuapata, en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, pollo, artículos de librería, regalos, En un inicio su tienda estaba en la casa de sus suegros y hace 2 meses se mucho a su casa, que construyo en el ultimo año, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hija y su esposo.

Miriam necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, fideo, aceite y leche.

Miriam sueña con tener una tienda al por mayor, sus hijos sean profesionales y ahorrar dinero para su vejez.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

Miriam is a member of the Communal Prosperity Bank. Miriam is 34 years old, married, and has 2 children; Miriam has a shop in her home in Quinuapata where she sells groceries, vegetables, chicken, gifts, etc. The shop began in the home of her in laws and 2 months ago she moved it to her new home which was built in the last year (done with the help of her daughter and her husband). Miriam needs a loan of 2000 soles that will be invested in the purchase of rice, noodles, milk and oil. Miriam dreams of having a wholesale shop, having children who are professionals and being able to save money for her old age.

loans.use: Miriam needs a loan of 2000 soles that will be invested in the purchase of rice, noodles, milk and oil.

loans.name: Eloisa Del Carmen

texts.es:
En el municipio de Nagarote de la cuidad de León en Nicaragua, la señora Eloisa S. se dedica desde hace 35 largos años al negocio de sastrería el cual atiende con el proposito de mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia que tato necesita de su apoyo.

Debido a que se ha desempeñado desde hace varios años a esta labor, ha logrado salir adelante gracias a los creditos proporcionados por Ceprodel. Hoy en dia, una vez mas solicita un credito para la compra de los materiales de trabajo como lo es hilos, telas, agujas y botones. Ella espera que su crédito sea otorgado para asi salir adelante en su negocio.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

In the municipality of Nagarote in the city of Leon in Nicaragua, Mrs. Eloisa S. has worked in the tailoring business for 35 long years; she works with the purpose of improving the living conditions of her family that need her support.

Since she has worked for several years in this business she has managed to succeed thanks to the loan given to her by Ceprodel. Today she is once again requesting a loan for the purchase of material for her work. These materials include thread, fabric, buttons and needles; she hopes that the loan is approved since it will allow her to succeed in her business.

loans.use: Purchase of materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a large stock of goods to replenish a small grocery store.

loans.name: Aurea

texts.es:
Aurea es socia del Banco Comunal Prosperidad.

Aurea es casada, tiene 39 años y 5 hijos, Aurea vende quesos de casa en casa, los quesos los adquiere de intermediarios que compran en las ferias, en el ultimo mes dejo de vender porque el queso ha subido mucho de precio. Aurea también viaja a la selva ayacuchana en donde vende cereales, quesos y tiene terrenos en donde cultiva cacao. Además Aurea y su esposo tienen una carpintería en su casa.

Aurea necesita un préstamo de 2000 dinero que será invertido en la compra de maderas y para el pago de peones.

Aurea sueña con equipar su carpintería con más maquinarias, que sus hijos terminen sus estudios, construir su casa e implementar una tienda.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

Aurea is a partner in the Communal Prosperity Bank.

Aurea is 39 years old, married and has 5 children. Aurea goes house to house selling cheese that she acquires from middlemen who sell them at markets; in the last month she stopped selling because cheese has risen significantly in price. Aurea also travels to the Ayacucho jungle where she sells cereals, cheeses and cocoa. Aurea and her husband also have a carpenter workshop at home.

Aurea needs a 2000 loan to invest in the purchase of timber and for the payment of workmen.

Aurea dreams of having her carpentry workshop with more machinery so that when her children finish their studies they can build their home and implement a store.

loans.use: She needs a 2000 loan to invest in the purchase of timber and for the payment of workmen.

loans.name: Esmelda

texts.es:
La señora Esmelda L. se dedica desde hace tres años al negocio de pulperia vendiendo todo tipo de ptroductos y granos basicos atendiendo en su casa de habitaicion. Es de necesidad destacar que con este trabajo se beneficia tatno ella como su familia compuesta por sus dos hijos en edad escolar.

Hoy en dia la necesidad que ella atraviesa es la urgencia de adquirir el capital economico para la compra de la mercadería y los granos basicos para comercializarlos. Por este motivo es que ella acude a Ceprodel para obtener el credito oportuno y asi salir adelante en su negocio. Es importante destacar que ella actualmente es una fiel cleinte habiendo cancelado el credito anterior en tiempo y forma de acuerdo a lo establecido.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

For three years Ms. Esmelda Lopez has had a business where she sells all kinds of basic grains and products in her home. It is important to emphasize that this work benefits all of her family including her two school aged children. Today she has an urgent need to acquire capital in order to purchase various products and basic grains and thus she has asked Ceprodel for a loan in order to help her succeed in her business. It is important to note that she is a faithful client and paid off her previous loan in a timely manner in accordance with the rules provided.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in jewelry in order to keep operating her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fashionable jewelry to retail in her community.

loans.name: Fanis Esperanza

texts.es:
La señora Fanis Gonzales se dedica al negocuio de elaboracion y venta de comida ofreciendola en su casa de habitacion y preparando variedad de platillos para su respectiva venta. Este negocio lo ha venido desarrollando desde hace 20 años y ha logrado con esto suplir las necesidades de sus dos hijos en edad escolar. A medida que han venido transcurriendo los años el negocio ha venido desarrollandose y esto gracias al apoyo brindado por Ceprodel el cual le ha proporcionado creditos los cuales los ha invertido directamente en la compra de la materia prima para su negocio. Hoy en dia una vez mas solicita un credito confiando que su peticion le será arpobada y de esta forma saldrá adelante en su negocio.

Translated from Spanish by Eliza Wethey, Kiva volunteer.

Ms. Fanis Gonzales works selling and cooking food in a room in her home where she prepares a variety of dishes for sale. She has been working in this business for 20 years and in doing so has been able to achieve the needs of her two school aged children. Over the years her business has grown thanks to the financial support provided by Ceprodel. She has used her previous loans to invest in the purchase of raw material for her business. Once again she has requested a loan confident that her request will be approved and thus will able to improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase of raw material

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in various goods so as to replenish her grocery store

loans.name: Yovana

texts.es:
Yovana was born in the community Checca, Llave. She is 23 years, and studied until the fifth year of secondary school. She lives with her partner, is mother to two daughters, aged 3 and 5, and currently lives in Jr. Santa Cruz s / n, Mazocruz. For a year now she has been a member of Banco Julia Jiménez, Santa Rosa, Collao, Puno. Six years ago she set up a carpentry workshop which she runs together with her husband, generally creating furniture such as wardrobes, tables, chairs, kitchen units and other items. With this loan S/.1700.00 Nuevos Soles, which she will pay in 4 installments, she will buy wood worth a thousand nuevos soles, 20 boxes of triplay. His dream is to have a furniture store and a hardware store in Mazocruz, and offer her children a good education so they can become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

Yovana nació en la comunidad de Checca – Distrito de Ilave, tiene 23 años de edad estudió quinto de secundaria, es conviviente, madre de dos hijas de 03 y 05 años, actualmente vive en el Jr. Santa Cruz s/n, Mazocruz. Es socia hace un año del Banco Julia Jiménez distrito de Santa Rosa Provincia del Collao – Puno, hace seis años instaló su taller de carpintería donde trabaja conjuntamente con su esposo, generalmente confecciona muebles como: roperos, mesas, sillas, reposteros y otros. Con este préstamo de S/.1,700.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, comprará madera valor de mil nuevos soles, 20 planchas de triplay . Su sueño es tener una tienda de muebles y una ferretería en la misma población de Mazocruz, y así poder educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.

loans.use: To buy wood and triplay

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suwardi

texts.id:
Verging on 49 years of age, Ni Ketut Suwardi is keen about developing her livestock business that she began six months ago. With a sufficiently permanent stable and two pigs for breeding, Ni Ketut Suwardi has already gained respectable earnings of Rp.1.000.000 (approx. US$109) in six months. However, Ni Ketut Suwardi has not had an opportunity to develop her business further with these earnings because she has been facing rising prices driven by increased gas prices. As a result, Ni Ketut Suwardi is eager for additional working capital from DINARI Foundation which can help her purchase feed and expand the number of her livestock.

Ni Ketut Suwardi not only works diligently on her business but also daily helps her husband in his work as a farmer. She does all this to sustain the family and finance their three kids. Although Ni Ketut Suwardi and her husband have not studied past elementary school, they yearn for all their children to undergo higher education. Developing this livelihood business, Ni Ketut Suwardi wishes to realize her dream of schooling her children to the highest level.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva volunteer.

Memasuki usia ke 49 tahun Ni Ketut Suwardi sangat bersemangat dalam mengembangkan usaha ternak babi yang baru dirintisnya sejak 6 bulan yang lalu. Dengan bermodalkan sebuah kandang yang cukup permanen dan 2 ekor ternak peliharaan, Ni Ketut Suwardi sudah mendapatkan keuntungan yang cukup lumayan yaitu Rp. 1.000.000.- / 6 bulan. Namun, belum sempat Ni Ketut Suwardi dapat mengembangkan usahanya dengan hasil keuntungan yang di peroleh , kini dia telah di hadapkan dengan permasalahan kenaikan harga barang-barang karena pengaruh kenaikan BBM ( Bahan Bakar Minyak ). Oleh karena itu Ni Ketut Suwardi sangat berharap bisa mendapatkan tambahan modal dari Dinari yang akan dipergunakan untuk menambah modal baik dalam pembelian bibit maupun untuk biaya pakannya , sehingga jumlah peliharaanya akan lebih banyak.

Dalam keseharianya Ni Ketut Suwardi sangat tekun dalam usaha maupun membantu pekerjaan suami yang bekerja sebagai seorang petani. Semua itu dia lakukan untuk menyambung hidup dan membiayai ke tiga orang anaknya. Meskipun hanya tamatan Sekolah Dasar, Ni Ketut Suardi dan Suami sangat merindukan semua anaknya bisa mengenyam pendidikan yang lebih tinggi . Dengan mengembangkan usaha ternak ini , besar harapan Ni Ketut Suwardi untuk dapat mewujudkan impiannya menyekolahkan anak bungsunya sampai ketingkat yang lebih tinggi.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Mr. Phon P., 45, is a farmer from the Trean Commune in Cambodia's Kampong Cham Province. He also relies on fishing as an additional income source to supplement his earnings from farming. He is married and has four children, one of whom is employed as a garment worker and who helps support Mr. Phon's loan repayment. His wife stays at home and cares for the children.

Rising family expenses have made it necessary for Mr. Phon to expand his business and earn more. Thus, he is requesting a loan to purchase more nets for his fishing business. He will use the remainder of the loan to purchase some piglets to raise. Mr. Phon and his wife are pictured.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing nets and some piglets to raise

loans.name: Ni Made Wiarti

texts.id:
I Komang Sumertama is very proud of her wife: Ni Made Wiarti. Born in 1975, Ni Made Wiarti is a faithful and hard working wife. She does not only housewife tasks but also raises piglets. The mother of I Nengah Edi Erawan (9 years old) is able to earn almost as much as her husband’s income.

Before the increase of fuel price, Ni Made Wiarti was able to earn IDR 700,000 per cycle, but the increase of goods price as the effect of the increase of fuel price, decrease her income. To purchase a piglet, she has to have IDR 325,000, and more to purchase the fodder. With the loan from DInari, Ni Made Wiarti expects to be able to increase the number of pigs she manages, which will be able to increase the income. She wants to save some of the income as a reserve for her boy’s education fund in the future.

Translated form Indonesian by Hestyana DK, Kiva volunteer.

I Komang Sumertama sangat bangga mempunyai Istri Ni Made Wiarti .Wanita kelahiran tahun 1975 ini begitu ulet dalam melakukan pekerjaanya, baik selaku ibu rumah tangga maupun membantu pekerjaan suaminya yang berprofesi sebagai petani dan semua pekerjaan itu dikerjakannya dengan cekatan dan telah menjadi rutinitas setiap hari mulai jam 8 pagi setelah menyelesaikan pekerjaan di dapur. Namun begitu, disela sela kesibukan itu, Ibu dari I Nengah Edi erawan (9 Th ) ini juga memiliki satu usaha yaitu beternak babi .Bahkan hasil yang di dapat tak beda jauh dengan pendapatan suaminya. Pendapatan yang cukup untuk menambah biaya kebutuhan hidup sehari-hari. Diawali dengan 2 ekor penggemukan yang di pelihara dalam waktu 6 bulan. Dulu Ni Made Wiarti bisa meraih keuntungan Rp. 700.000.- / panen . Namun setelah terjadinya perubahan perekonomian akibat kenaikan BBM semua barang barang pun ikut naik. Begitu juga halnya dengan bibit babi maupun pakannya. Untuk membeli satu ekor bibit babi sekarang I Made Wiarti harus menyediakan uang Rp. 325.000.- belum lagi biaya pakan yang sangat tinggi. Namun, Ni Made Wiarti tak mau menyerah begitu saja walau dengan modal pinjaman dari Dinari, ia tetap menjalankan usahanya ini bahkan jumlah peliharaanya pun lebih banyak. Tentunya juga dengan harapan hasil panennya lebih banyak sehingga keuntungannya jadi meningkat. Dengan demikian Ni Made Wiarti bisa menabung untuk persiapan biaya pendidikan anaknya.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and fodder

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Natri

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Natri has a very simple cage, with bamboo construction and woven coconut tree leaves as ceiling to breed pigs. She has started the business since she got married with I Made Peleng. Up to now, Ni Nyoman Natri is still running the business, for it has been able to give additional income that Improve their family’s economic condition. After their children got married, Ni Nyoman Natri only lives with husband.

Ni Nyoman Ratri runs the business enthusiastically. She manages the breed in between with her activity managing the farmland. Before earning loan from Dinari, she ran the business with only IDR 400,000, which was deployed to purchase 2 local piglets that have been raised traditionally. Limited capital has sometimes forced Ni Nyoman Natri to sell the pigs before they are mature. She has to do that because her family sometimes need extra money, that she cannot purchase fodder for the pigs. The price of fodder and piglets are quite expensive.

With the motivation to improve the business, Ni Nyoman Natri proposed loan from Dinari. She plans to use the loan to purchase piglets that will be raised to reproduce piglets that in the future she can sell piglets for other breeders. She is confident that the loan, combined with her hard working, will be very useful, that she will be able to increase her income.

Translated form Indonesian by Hestyana DK, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Nyoman Natri memiliki kandang yang sangat sederhana , dinding bambu dan atap daun kelapa yang di anyam. Ni Nyoman Natri telah memulai usaha beternak babi sejak menikah dengan I Made Peleng. Sampai saat ini Ni Nyoman Natri masih tetap menekuni usaha itu karena dengan beternak babi ia bisa mendapat tambahan penghasilan untuk membantu pendapatan keluarga. Ni Nyoman Natri tinggal berdua dengan suaminya setelah anaknya menikah. Ni Nyoman Natri sangat berantusias untuk mengembangkan usaha ternak babi yang sedang di tekuni. Hal ini dilakukannya untuk mengisi waktu luang sebelum dan setelah bekerja sebagai petani di kebun miliknya. Sebelum mendapat pinjaman dari Dinari, Ni Nyoman Natri hanya mengandalkan modal Rp. 400.000.- untuk membeli 2 ekor bibit babi lokal yang di pelihara secara tradisional. Dengan modal yang sangat terbatas itu sering kali Ni Nyoman Natri harus menjual ternaknya sebelum waktu panen karena kebutuhan keluarga yang mendesak atau tak sanggup membeli pakan. Apalagi saat ini harga bibit dan pakan cukup tinggi. Kerja keras dan kemauan yang kuat untuk mengembangkan usahanya , Ni Nyoman Natri melakukan pinjaman di Dinari yang di pergunakan untuk membeli bibit Induk sehingga kedepan tak lagi membeli bibit bahkan bisa menyediakan bibit untuk peternak yang lain . Dengan tambahan modal itu kini Ni Nyoman Natri merasa lebih tenang dan yakin akan mendapat hasil yang lebih baik dari pada sebelumnya.

loans.use: To purchase breeder

loans.name: Tha

texts.en:
Mr. Tha Y., 43, is a farmer and fisherman living with his wife and three children in Trean Commune, Kampong Cham Province. Mr. Tha has been farming since 1990 and typically earns around $1 per day. One of his children is employed as a construction worker in Kampong Cham town.

To help increase his family's income, Mr. Tha seeks to expand his fishing business. Thus, he is requesting a loan to purchase fishing tools such as a boat and nets. Mr. Tha and his wife are pictured.

loans.use: To request a loan to purchase fishing tools such as a boat and nets

loans.name: Ni Ketut Mertini

texts.id:
Eventhough getting older, Ni Ketut Mertini is not losing hope. She is still striving to move forward, either with the organization within her village, or with the business she runs. She is a hard worker, and always energetic in doing everything, especially in running her business: piglets breeding.

Ni Ketut Mertini is the wife of I Made Kompiang. They have 3 children. Eventhough she is now 54 years old, Ni Ketut Mertini is still eager to run the business. She manages 2 cages with 2-4 pigs. The cages have never been empty. The limited number of pigs she raise is just because the limited capital. The income Ni Ketut Mertini earns is varied, between IDR 100,000 to IDR 250,000 a month, that is used to fulfill her family’s daily needs and to pay her children tuition fees.

Ni Ketut Mertini is planning to increase the number of the pigs she manages and to develop the existing cages. She proposes to borrow IDR 3,500,000 through Dinari. Ni Ketut Mertini is optimistic that her business will be improved if she is entrusted the loan.

Translated form Indonesian by Hestyana DK, Kiva volunteer.

Usia yang semakin tua tak menyurutkan semangat dari Ni Ketut Mertini untuk maju, baik dalam berbagai organisasi di desanya maupun dalam usaha yang sedang di gelutinya. Istri dari I Made Kompiang ini terkenal sangat tekun dan selalu energik dalam segala kegiatannya, terlebih dalam hal berternak babi. 54 tahun sudah umur ibu dengan tiga orang anak ini. Tetapi dia tampak masih sangat bersemangat untuk mengembangkan usahanya. Dua buah kandang semi permanen miliknya tak pernah kosong dari babi –babi peliharaan walau jumlahnya berkisar dua sampai empat ekor saja. Itu karena modal yang di miliki sangat terbatas. Keuntungan yang di dapat Ni Ketut Mertini selama ini bervariasi, yaitu berkisar Rp. 100.000.- sampai Rp. 250.000.- per bulannya. Hasil ini dia pergunakan untuk membantu memenuhi kebutuhan keluarga dan pendidikan ke tiga orang anaknya. Ni Ketut Mertini bermaksud menambah jumlah ternak peliharaannya yang saat ini hanya dua ekor dan juga memperbaiki kandang yang ada. Untuk mewujudkan hal itu, Ni Ketut Mertini membutuhkan tambahan modal lagi yang dia pinjam melalui Dinari Rp. 3.500.000.- Dengan tambahan modal ini Ni Ketut Mertini optimis usahanya akan lebi

loans.use: To purchase piglets and renovate the cage

loans.name: Ni Luh Kanten

texts.id:
Ni Luh Kanten started her business, to raise 2 piglets, with IDR 200,000 to purchase each piglet. She at first raised the piglets traditionally, by tying them on a tree, but now she has had a semi-permanent cage. The high price of piglet and the fodder has ever made Ni Luh Kanten confused and stopped the business that make her family’s economic condition shocked, for the family only depends on the income earned from her husband who works as a labor. Finally, with the support from his husband, Ketut Sarnen, Ni Luh Kanten started to fulfill her cage with piglets again, with the capital earned from the loan from Dinari. The loan was deployed to purchase 4 piglets, IDR 300,000 each. The rest of the loan was used to buy fodder. Now, Ni Luh Kanten is optimistic with the business, and hopes that the business will be able to change their economic condition, as well as to support the the education for her children.

Translated form Indonesian by Hestyana DK, Kiva volunteer.

Dari dua ekor ternak babi yang di beli seharga Rp. 200.000,- / ekornya Ni Luh Kanten memulai usahanya. Dari pemeliharaan sistem tradisional (mengikat babi di bawah pohon ) hingga kini telah memiliki sebuah kandang yang semi permanen. Harga bibit babi dan pakan ternak yang mahal sempat membuat Ni Luh Kanten bingung dan mengosongkan kandangnya dan hal itu sangat berdampak pada perekonomian keluarga yang hanya bertumpu pada pendapatan suaminya yang berprofesi sebagai buruh. Untuk mengatasi hal tersebut, akhirnya berkat dorongan dari Ketut Sernen, suaminya, saat ini Niluh Kanten mulai lagi mengisi kandangnya dengan ternak babi baru dengan menggunakan dana pinjaman dari Dinari. Dana yang didapatnya dibelikannya 4 ekor bibit babi yang masing-masing seharga Rp. 300.000.- sedangkan sisa uangnya di belikan pakan ternak seperti dedak padi, dedak gandum dan konsentrat. Ni Luh Kanten kini merasa sangat optimis dengan usaha yang dijalankan saat ini dan berharap modal yang di berikan ini akan bisa mengubah dan memperbaiki perekonomian keluarganya yang sempat terpuruk dan juga untuk biaya pendidikan anaknya.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and fodder

loans.name: Mrs. Soam Mach Group

texts.en: Mrs. Soam M. is the leader of this four member group in Phum Thom Village in Kandal Province. She is a cake maker and seller who earns a small income to support her family. Since her business is doing well, Mrs. Soam M. wants to make more cakes, so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients to make cakes to sell door-to-door. Her husband, Mr. Eb Pheng, is a construction worker. Mrs. Soam M. is 48 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the one is a construction worker. The remaining two attend school.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients to make cakes to sell door-to-door.

loans.name: Mrs. Rath Kong Group

texts.en: This group, which combines six members is located in Yok Bath Village in the Kandal Province and Mrs. Rath K. is the group leader. She is a vegetable seller. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to resell to her customers. Mrs. Rath K. is a 47-year-old widow with five children, two of whom help her in the business activity while the others are attending school.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to resell to her customers.

loans.name: Mrs. Meas Saven Group

texts.en: This group, which is located in Sdaov Kanlaeng Village in Kandal Province consists of five people and Mrs. Meas S. is the group leader who has been selected by the members. She owns a small restaurant. from which she sells soup to people in the local village. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients in order to cook delicious soup for her customers.  Mrs. Meas S. is a 61-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, whilst the other is a driver in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients in order to cook delicious soup for her customers.

loans.name: Mrs. Saem Touch Group

texts.en: Mrs. Saem T. is the leader of this 5 member group, located in the Kandal Province of Cambodia. She runs her business selling her home-made Khmer cakes. Her business is going very well and she has a lot of customers. In order to reach her customers’ demand, Mrs. Saem T. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase more sticky rice and other goods to make Khmer cakes. Mrs. Saem T. is a 46-year-old widow with four children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory worker, whilst the other attends school. The remaining one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to purchase more sticky rice and others material to make Khmer cake.

loans.name: Mrs. Khut Nary Group

texts.en: This group, which located in Chrouy Ampil Thmey Village in Kandal Province consists of four members and Mrs. Khut N. is the group leader who was born in 1957.  She owns a small grocery store in the local village. Her business is going well and she now wants to expand it. She has therefore decided to ask for a loan to buy more grocery goods for her inventory. Her husband, Mr. Doem Duong, is a construction worker who generates a small income to support his family. Mrs. Khut N. is 51 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other two assist their parents business. The remaining three are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods for her inventory.

loans.name: Mrs. Hong Nari Group

texts.en: Mrs. Hong N. is the group leader of five who all live in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie Village in Kandal Province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Sok Bunthoeun owns a small cart -which he attaches to his motorbike with a cable -in order to transport soil to sell door-to-door.  However, his business now faces a problem because the cable he uses to attach his cart to his motorbike is broken. Therefore, his wife, Mrs. Hong N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a new cable. Mrs. Hong N. is 26 years old and the mother of a child who is only four months old.

loans.use: to buy a new cable to attach a cart

loans.name: Mr. Chuob Choeurn Group

texts.en: This group is located in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie Village in Kandal Province and consists of four people. Mr. Chuob C. is the group leader. He is a motorbike taxi driver who makes a small income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. PH. Nop is a mat maker. Since her business is going well and she also has a lot of customers, she has decided to expand her business. Unfortunately, she does not have enough money to purchase more raw materials to make a mats so her husband, Mr. Chuob C., would like to request a loan for this purpose. Mr. Chuob C. is 50 years old and the father of four children one of whom is working as a security guard Company while another one helps Mrs. PH. Nop's business. The remaining two are attending school.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make mats to sell.

loans.name: Sari Mertha Group

texts.id:
Live in a village and work as farmer is not an easy way. One should work very hard, with uncertain result. To increase their income, some farmers choose to breed cattle. The activity is also done by several house wives in Dsn. Sari Kuning, Tukadaya Village, West Bali. They do the business in a group with 15 members. The group is managed by 3 committees whose responsible to coordinate the members in running the business. All the members do the same business: to breed pigs.

Doing the business in a group, let them to earn capital easier, and within the group they are able to help each other. The loan from KIVA through DINARI, which is IDR 1,000,000 for each member, will be deployed to purchase high quality fodder and piglets for a period (6 months). The additional capital and assistance from DINARI, are expected to be able to increase the business. All of the members are sure that their income will increase, that they will be able to improve their family's economic condition.

Translated form Indonesian by Hestyana DK, Kiva volunteer.

Hidup di desa dan bekerja sebagai petani ternyata tidak mudah, butuh kerja keras namun terkadang hasilnya tidak makssimal. Untuk menambah penghasilan mereka ada beberapa petani yang memilih untuk beternak. Hal ini juga dilakukan oleh sekelompok ibu-ibu yang berada di Dsn. Sari Kuning, Ds. Tukadaya, Bali Barat. Kelompok ini terdiri dari 15 anggota dan memiliki 3 orang pengurus yang bertanggung jawab untuk mengkoordinir kelompok tersebut dalam menjalankan usaha mereka. Semua anggota kelompok memiliki usaha yang sama yaitu sebagai peternak babi. Keunggulan dari usaha beternak secara berkelompok adalah memudahkan mereka dalam mendapatkan modal usaha serta mereka saling menbantu dalam menjalankan usaha ternak mereka. Pinjaman yang diperoleh dari KIVA melalui DINARI sebesar Rp. 1.000.000,- per anggota dipergunakan sebagai tambahan modal usaha yaitu untuk membeli pakan yang berkualitas dan membeli bibit yang akan dipelihara selama satu kali periode pemeliharaan (6 bulan). Dengan mendapat tambahan modal serta pendampingan dari DINARI kelompok ini mulai mengalami peningkatan dalam usaha dan mereka sangat yakin akan mendapatkan hasil yang lebih baik sehingga ekonomi keluarga merekapun bisa lebih baik dari sekarang.

loans.use: To purchase fodder and high quality piglets Membeli

loans.name: Mrs. Dul Sam Arth Village Bank Group

texts.en: This group consists of eight members in Boeng Krum Kraom Village in Kandal Province and Mrs. Dul S. A. is the group president. She works as a fish seller in the local market. She sells the fish which her husband catches. However, Mr. Sao Ven now faces a problem because he does not have enough nets to catch his fish. Therefore, his wife, Mrs. Dul S. A. has decided to ask for a loan to buy more fishing nets so that he can catch more fish. Mrs. Dul S. A. is 29 years old and the mother of two. One of her children attends school whilst the other is only three years old.

loans.use: to buy more fishing nets in order to gather fish to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Phan Navy Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank, which consists of twelve people is located in Ta Skor Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Phan N. is the Village Bank President and she is a house wife. Her husband, Mr. Im Sophak, is a fisherman who now faces a small problem in his business because he does not have enough fishing equipment. In order to improve his business, Mrs. Phan N. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fishing nets for her husband’s business. Mrs. Phan N. is 36 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are employed in small positions in a TV Company whilst the other three are attending the local school. The youngest one is only one year old.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets for her husband business.

loans.name: Yeom

texts.en: Mrs. Yeom L. was born in 1947 and she now lives in Thmey Village in Kandal Province. She is a fisherman who now faces a problem with her business because she does not have enough fishing equipment to gather her fish. In order to catch more fish, Mrs. Yeom L. has decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat. She intends to use the rest of the loan to buy fish nets. Mrs. Yeom L. has two children one of whom assists Mrs. Yeom L.'s business while the other one is a labourer who makes a small income which he uses to help support the family.

loans.use: to buy a boat and fishing nets.

loans.name: Ra

texts.en:
Mrs. Ra S., 36, is a porridge seller in her village and lives with her husband in Kampong Choeung Commune, Kampong Thom Province. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver. Mrs. Ra and her husband work hard every day to generate income for their family's expenses and to pay school fees expenses for their children.

Rising family expenses have made it necessary for the couple to earn more income. Thus, Mrs. Ra is requesting a loan to purchase piglets to raise and to construct a pigpen.

loans.use: To use for pig raising operation; purchase piglets to raise and make pigpen

loans.name: Huorn

texts.en: Mr. Huorn T. was born in 1968 and he now lives in Srae Ampil Village in Kandal Province.  He has a motorbike with a cart attaches, which he uses to transport passengers and goods. At the moment, this business is not very profitable because his motorbike uses a lot of gasoline. He has therefore decided to ask for a loan so that he can buy a more efficient motorbike. His wife, Mrs. Ya Chroeb, is a sugar cane juice seller in the local village. Mr Huorn T. has four children who are all attending school. His wife is shown on the left of the photograph.

loans.use: to replace his old motorbike with a new one.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en: This will be the second time that Mrs. Pich N. has taken out a loan in order to improve her living conditions. She and her husband are fishermen in Thmey Village in Kandal Province and they make a small profit from their business. They have five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending school. Mrs. Pich N. currently finds cooking very difficult because she does not have a kitchen. In order to cook delicious food for her family, Mrs. Pich N. decided to ask for a loan to buy timber to build a kitchen in their the backyard. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: to buy timber to build a kitchen in their backyard.

loans.name: Nann

texts.en: This the second time of Mrs. Nann T. is asking for a loan to improve her living conditions. She is a farmer in Thmey Village in Kandal Province. Her husband, Mr. Sreng Sun, is a fisherman in the local lake. Mrs. Nann T. is 46 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a scarf sewer while the remaining two are attending school. Although the family members have different businesses, they still do not have enough money to buy lumber to make a wall to protect them from rain. Thus, Mrs. Nann T. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy lumber to make a wall to protect them from rain.

loans.name: Luk

texts.en: This the second time Mrs. Luk K. has taken out a loan to improve her business activity. She sells lottery tickets in the village of Thmey in Kandal Province. Her husband, Mr. Sen Kloeng, is a fisherman and he now faces a problem in his business because he does not have enough fishing equipments to gather fish, especially a boat. In order to improve this business, his wife, Mrs. Luk K., decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy a motor for it. Mrs. Luk K. is 55 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom helps the father with his business while two assist their mother in business. The remaining three are attending school. Mrs. Luk K. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: to buy a new boat and a motor for it

loans.name: Nurn

texts.en: This is the second time Mrs. Nurn S. has asked for a loan to improve her standard of living. She and her husband are fishermen in the local lake in Thmey Village in Kandal Province. They have three children; one is a fisherman while another one is employed in a garment factory. The remaining one is enrolled in school. Although the family members have different business activities, they still live in an old house and poor conditions, and the house is always leaking while it is raining. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Nurn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy zinc to replace the old roof, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy fishnets for her business. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy zinc to replace the old roof and fishnets for her business.

loans.name: Hing

texts.en: Mrs. Hing O. is a villager in Roka Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband are farmers. They have four children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the remaining one is attending school. On the plantation, Mrs. Hing O. faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy rice seeds to cultivate. Thus, Mrs. Hing O. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose, and she would use the part of the loan to buy fertilizerfor her field.

loans.use: She would use the part of the loan to buy fertilizer for her field, the other part for seeds

loans.name: Aom

texts.en: Mrs. Aom K. is a farmer in Roka Village in Kandal Province. She is a 33-year-old widow with three children who are all employed in a garment factory. Mrs. Aom K. now faces a small problem because she does not have oxen to plow her rice field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings and to buy two oxen in order plow the field for cultivating.

loans.use: To buy two oxen in order plow the field for cultivating.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: This is the third time Mr. Nhen Sopheap has taken out a loan to improve his living conditions. He and his wife, Mrs. Sam S., are farmers in Dounvong Village in Kandal Province. They have five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while two others are attending school. The youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is age four. Although the family members have different business activities, they still cannot afford to buy lumber to build a new house. In order to do this, Mrs. Nhen Sopheap decided to ask for a loan to build a new house.

loans.use: To build a new house in order to improve his living conditions.

loans.name: Jamila's Takrima Group

texts.en:
Jamila is 40 years old, married with three children aged 20, 16 and 9. Jamila has been selling fish, shoes and clothes since 2002, working long days from 6am to 10pm. She earns a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Jamila now hopes for a loan to increase her inventory. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, who have livestock, charcoal, juice and clothing businesses.

loans.use: To buy more fish, shoes and clothes for sale.

loans.name: Kitimbwa Mixed Group

texts.en:
Rose N. is the chairperson of the Kitimbwa mixed group. She is married with 7 children and looks after 2 kids that belong to her siblings. Over the past few months, Rose has been able to improve her retail shop, as well as starting to farm. Now things seem to be going well, except that in her shop she lacks a fridge for selling cold drinks, and she needs to restock her shop with more products like sugar, salt, cooking oil, baking powder, and soft drinks so that by the end of the holiday season, she has saved enough to take care of her children's school fees and home care.

Rose does not regret being the leader of her group because this has taught her many leadership skills that she lacked before. She says that farming takes a long time to bring in revenue, but when the time is ripe, she is all smiles. Look at the baby that Rose had when she took her first loan in October 2007: he is really grown up and stubborn because she is able to care for her baby and the rest of her children with profits from the loans. She is asking for a loan to help her buy a fridge, soft drinks, sugar, salt, cooking oil, and baking powder in large quantities to prevent her from over-spending on transport costs.

loans.use: Rose is asking for a loan to help her buy a fridge, soft drinks, sugar, salt, cooking oil, and baking powder in large quantities for her shop.

loans.name: Salama's Tusonge Mbele Group

texts.en:
Salama is a 47-year-old widow with three adult children aged 25, 23 and 21. She has been a porridge seller for the past 14 years and earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Salama hopes for a loan to increase her stock. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, Husna and Maryam, who sell soap and clothing.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

loans.name: Salma's Tusongembele Group

texts.en:
Salma is 40 years old. She is married with four children aged between 5 and 16 years old. She started her fish selling business in 2007, putting in 14-hour days at work. She earns a monthly profit of about $25.

Salma wants to use this loan to increase her inventory of fish. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, who have a variety of businesses including selling clothing, eggs and juice.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of fish.

loans.name: Fatma's Tusongembele Group

texts.en:
Fatma is a charcoal and firewood seller. She is 26 years old and is married with three children aged 6, 4 and 3. Each day she works 14 hours, from 7am to 9pm, and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, who have businesses dealing with tailoring, charcoal sales, fine art and kiosks.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood.

loans.name: Fatma Takrima Group

texts.en:
Fatma is 31 years old, married with a 6-year-old child. She has been a clothes seller since 2002. She works 13 hours a day, from 6am to 7pm, and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Fatma now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, who have a variety of businesses including a juice kiosk, tailoring, clothes and perfumes sales.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of clothes.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is a married woman from Laktasi. Her husband doesn't work, as he is a pensioner. Vida sells cosmetic and sanitary products. She buys her goods wholesale and then resells them to her customers. She can earn about 500 KM monthly.

This is Vida's third loan from Women to Women International, and she is asking for 600 KM. Vida will use the money to buy more sanitary and cosmetic products to sell in order to earn more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic and sanitary products to sell

loans.name: Khaitgul

texts.en:
Khaitgul A. is 36 years old. She is divorced with three children. She started a clothing sales business in her home town of Shahrituz in order to pay for personal expenses and the education of her children. She started with a little merchandise, and little by little she has increased her sales and clientele. It has not been easy for Khaitgul to shoulder all of the responsibilities of her house, but the love of her children makes it worth it. In the photo you see Khaitgul’s eldest daughter, who helps her mother with the business.

Today Khaitgul needs a loan of 3100 Somoni (925 USD) to buy new merchandise in order to have new products and attract new clients. She promises to repay this loan in 6 months. You can contribute to improving the living conditions of this family. Your help is a great blessing for them.

loans.use: Purchase of new children’s clothing to broaden her inventory

loans.name: Kitimbwa Group

texts.en: Emmanuel T. is 39 and married with 8 children and cares for 1 dependent. He is the treasure of Kitimbwa mixed group and the leader of his lending group. His 15-year-old shop is doing very well, and over the years it has enabled him to start other businesses like selling used clothing and keeping chickens at home with the help of loans. His wife helps with shopkeeping while he sells his used clothing to the various markets using his bicycle. He has a plan to buy a motorcycle to help in his trade, but capital is still lacking because a good motorcycle costs over $1550, while at the same time his shop still needs restocking plus soliciting fees for his school-going children. He is saving toward buying a motorcycle and will be happy to let everyone know when he buys it. Right now he needs a loan to be able to restock his shop as well as buy bales of clothes for sale.

loans.use: Emmanuel needs a loan to be able to restock his shop as well as buy bales of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.en:
Gulsara C. is a 51-year-old woman. She is a widow with three children. They live in the town of Shahrituz, Tajikistan. Gulsara sells national fabrics at the local market. She works in a sphere of trade where the demand is always very consistent and high because the national dresses in Tajikistan are very popular and very important dowry items for any girl. Gulsara has been in this business for 12 years. She has always been an active and enthusiastic entrepreneur. Now her children are grown up and they always try to help their mother with the business, as you can see in this photo of Gulsara’s eldest son.

Today Gulsara is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) for the term of 3 months to increase her available capital. She believes the profits she will be able to generate will not only help her keep a stable position in the market but will also offer a better livelihood for her grandkids. Gulsara has been a role model of discipline, accuracy and responsibility. Difficult family circumstances and ill health have not hindered consistent growth in her business. IMON (Kiva’s Field Partner) believes her perseverant work and natural liveliness will help Gulsara continue to succeed in her trade and repay this loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of new fabric to broaden her selection of goods

loans.name: Milena

texts.en:
Milena is a 41 year old woman from the small village of Kožuhe, near the town Doboj. She works at a petrol station, and her monthly salary is 400 KM. Sometimes Milena sells fruits and vegetables at the market during the weekend to supplement her income, and she needs a reliable car to drive her goods to the market.

This is Milena’s first loan through "Women for Women International," and she is asking for 1000 KM. She will use this loan to repair her car, so that she may sell her wares at the market.

loans.use: To repair her car so that she may sell vegetables and fruits at the market.

loans.name: Siajabu's Takrima Group

texts.en:
Siajabu is 30 years old, married with two children aged 10 and 7. She also takes care of another child, who is 13 years old. She opened her tailoring and clothes business in 2000. Working from 7am to 8pm each day she earns a monthly profit of about $40.

Siajabu requests a loan to buy more tailoring items and clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, whose businesses include a book shop, sales of charcoal, firewood, coconuts and clothes, and a home utensils shop.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring items and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.en:
Zuhro D., 36 years old, is a very dynamic and ambitious woman. She is putting a lot of effort into providing good education and food for her three children.

Zuhro has three adorable children. Being single and the only bread winner, she has had to work very hard to support her family. Zuhro is an enterprising woman, and she decided to start her own business selling children’s clothing and women’s handbags seven years ago in order to offer her children a better quality of life and to give them everything they need. Little by little she has made her business grow, and since offering her clients the option to pay in installments her orders have been getting bigger.

Now, Zuhro needs a loan of 600 Somoni (200 USD), which she will use to buy merchandise to cover the demand of her clients and to offer better service. She promises to repay the loan in 4 months. Be an important part in the life of this family! They are very grateful for your trust and support.

loans.use: Purchase of new children’s clothing to expand inventory

loans.name: Ruzuna's Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Ruzuna is divorced with five children between the ages of 3 and 14. She is a tailor and juice and card seller. She works from 7am to 10pm daily and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her businesses.

Ruzuna hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items and to increase her juice inventory. She will share this loan with her sub-group members, whose businesses include sales of juice, soap, tea, kerosene and clothing.

loans.use: To buy tailoring items and increase her inventory of juices.

loans.name: Orzigul

texts.en:
Orzigul K. is 47 years old. She is a single mother of one daughter. She has been through a very tough time, but she has been able to move forward and to take good care of her family. Orzigul currently sells clothing for children and women’s handbags which she buys from the neighboring city Dushanbe, the capital of our country (Tajikistan), which is located about 4 hours from where she lives.

She started with a small side business from her home. Thanks to her good-nature, she has been able to grow her clientele. She currently has two stores. Her main motivation is to provide a good education to her only daughter and to improve their family living condition. Today she is requesting a loan of 1500 Somoni (450USD) for the term of 12 months to purchase new, more expensive clothing before the autumn season. IMON (Kiva’s Field Partner) believes Orzigul’s willingness to offer her customers greater value and a wider choice of merchandise, combined with her excellent service, will secure the successful growth of her trade and guarantee good profits from sales. You can help support the well-being of this brave woman and her daughter.

loans.use: Purchase of new clothing for kids in order to broaden her inventory

loans.name: Fauzia

texts.en:
Fauzia is a widow with three children aged 10, 6 and six months. She is a clothes seller, working from 7am to 9pm every day. She earns a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Fauzia requests a loan to buy more clothes to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Nguvu Self-Help Group

texts.en:
Gilbert is a leader and member of Nguvu Self-Help Group. He is 31 and married with four children. Gilbert has been operating a small retail shop on the main road of Suneka town for four years. He started his shop after saving money from his former job for several years.

Gilbert is a kind and hardworking man. From the profits he is able to feed, clothe, and educate his children. With the assistance of the loan, Gilbert will increase stock for his shop. He is excited to purchase some new items, which he believes will generate more income. Gilbert is beaming with optimism about the busy economic season that runs from September through January in Kenya. His long-term business goal is to open up a wholesale unit in the future.

In addition to his retail shop, Gilbert has diversified into livestock. He owns one dairy cow and ten chickens. Selling the milk and eggs add another stream of income towards his overall profits.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Increase stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Msitu

texts.en:
Msitu is 45 years old. She is divorced with three children aged 16, 14 and 5. Msitu sells cereals, a business she started in 2002. Her monthly profit is about $25.

Msitu requests a loan to buy more cereals to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of cereals.

loans.name: Maryam's Takrima Group

texts.en:
Maryam is 48 years old. She is married with two children aged 22 and 18. She has been selling charcoal and firewood since 2002, working from 8am to 9pm and earning a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Maryam hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Venu, who sells clothing.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood.

loans.name: Kitimbwa Group

texts.en:
Sarah B. is the leader of her subgroup of the Kitimbwa mixed group in Kayunga. She is a single mother with 3 kids; 1 is 9 years old and the other 2 are 18-month-old twins. Sarah's story is a sad one: she was abandoned by her husband while she was on the ropes, after she developed a mental illness as a result of trouble with her co-wife, with whom the husband stays now. Her sister helped to care for her in that state, and worst of all, she was in the final stages of her pregnancy, which no one knew was twins.

With constant medication using native medicine, Sarah was able to recover slowly only to be told by people that she had 3-month-old twins. She thought of what to do but had no money to do anything at the moment, but since she had worked in the salon during those happy days with her husband, she couldn't settle for anything else.

Sarah started her salon with $100 from her only sister, and once she was set, she was introduced to the Kitimbwa mixed group that has surely given her a rebirth. She is now able to buy braids for plaiting her customers' hair, who like the way she twists their hair. She has a dream of enlarging her salon so that she is able to lay a strong foundation for her children, whose father has publicly abandoned them. She is a strong woman with a drive to succeed.

Sarah needs a loan to help her buy more braids, weaves, and chemicals for treating her customers' hair. Surely I was driven to visit Sarah in her salon, which is not very far away from where her group meets every Thursday. She now wants to restock her salon by buying braids, weaves, chemicals and lotions so that she can save and buy a drier in future.

loans.use: Sarah needs to restock her salon by buying braids, weaves, chemicals, and lotions.

loans.name: Biyam

texts.en:
Biyam is 26 years old, married with three children aged 9, 5 and 1. Biyam sells soap, potatoes and charcoal and has been doing so since 2005. She earns a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Biyam is seeking a loan to increase her stock and so improve her business.

loans.use: To increase her stock levels.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en: Fatma is a 40-year-old married woman with three children, ages 15, 9 and 3. She has been selling clothes since 2006.  Fatma works every day and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales. She is requesting a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Akiba's Tusongembele Group

texts.en:
Akiba, 42, is married with one 18-year-old child. She sells bedsheets and fish and works from 7AM to 5PM. She can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Akiba is requesting a loan to increase her inventory of bedsheets and fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Ndeure, who has a business dealing with tailoring and juice sales.

loans.use: To buy more bedsheet and fish for resale.

loans.name: Zakia

texts.en: Zakia is a 29-year-old married woman with three children, ages 8, 4 and 2. She also takes care of a 19-year-old person. Zakia has owned a small grocery store since in 2007. She works from 7AM to 9PM each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales. Zakia hopes to get a loan to buy more food items for her shop.

loans.use: To buy more food items for resale.

loans.name: Madina

texts.en: Madina, 30, is divorced with two children, ages 9 and 6. She also takes care of a 60-year-old person in her home. Madina has been selling firewood since 2007. She works from 6AM to 6PM every day and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales. Madina is requesting a loan to buy more firewood for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood for resale

loans.name: Hawa's Tusonge Mbele Group

texts.en:
Hawa, 38, is married with four children, age 20, 15, 11, and 6. She has been a clothes (vitenge) and bites salesperson since 2006. She works from 6AM to 5PM each day and earns a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Hawa is requesting a loan to buy more items to increase her current stock. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mariam, who also has a business dealing with bites and juice sales.

loans.use: To increase the current inventory for higher sales.

loans.name: Željka

texts.en:
Željka lives in the town of Doboj with her husband and child. Her husband works in construction and earns 600 KM per month. Željka works as a cleaner in a medical centre. During her free time, she works in agriculture.

Željka is asking for a loan of 500 KM to buy chickens to breed during the winter. She will fatten the chickens and sell them for additional household income during the winter. This business will keep her family solvent until she can begin her agricultural practice again in the spring.

loans.use: To buy chickens to fatten and sell.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en: Rukia, 23, is married with a one-year-old child. She has been a clothes (khanga) and cosmetics saleperson since 2006. She works from 8AM to 4PM at her business. Rukia is requesting a loan to buy more khanga and cosmetics items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes (khanga) and cosmetics items for her business.

loans.name: Hadia

texts.en: Hadia is 32-years-old and is married with two children, ages 15 and 2. She has been selling charcoal and coconuts since 2003. She works from 8AM to 6PM each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales. Hadia is requesting a loan to buy more charcoal and coconuts for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and coconuts for resale

loans.name: Zainab's Vegetable Sales Group

texts.en:
Zainab, 24, is married with one child. She has been selling tomatoes and potatoes since 2006. She works from 6AM to 6PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $145 from her sales.

Zainab has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She is now requesting a loan to buy more potatoes and tomatoes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Mwanausi, who has a business dealing with coconut and bite sales.

loans.use: To buy more tomatoes and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is 35-years-old, is married and has five children. She has been selling clothes and bites since 2004. Farida works from 8AM to 6PM every day, and can earn a monthly profit of $250 from her sales.

Farida has taken out one successful loan to expand her business and now hopes for another loan to buy more clothes to further expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: This is the second time Mr. Chen B. has asked for a loan to improve his business. He is a motorbike taxi driver in Sounvong Village in Kandal Province. He now faces a problem because his motorbike is too old and he uses a lot of money on gasoline to support his motorbike. In order to reduce family expenses on gasoline, Mr. Chen B. decided to ask for a loan to add to his savings and to buy a new a motorbike for his business. His wife, Mrs. Bun Khoen, is a housewife. Mr. Chen B. is 60 years old and the father of five children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the remaining two are attending school.

loans.use: to add to his savings to buy a new a motorbike for his business.

loans.name: Roeurn

texts.en: This is the second time Mrs. Roeurn S. has asked for a loan to improve her living conditions. She lives in Dounvong Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Roeurn S. and her husband, Mr. Phal Pros, are employed in a garment factory. Since their workplace is too far from home, Mrs. Roeurn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for transportation to work, and she hopes to reduce the family expenses in this way. Mrs. Roeurn S. is 31 years old and the mother of three children who are all too young to work or attend school because they are four, two years old and six months.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation to work.

loans.name: Mwanakombo's Food Sales Group

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a 48-year-old married woman. She has been selling juice, bites and coconuts since 1998. She works from 8AM to 8PM each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Mwanakombo has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She is requesting a new loan to increase her inventory. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Siti, who has a business selling soup and bites.

loans.use: To increase her inventory for higher sales

loans.name: Rahma's General Store Group

texts.en:
Rahma, 38, is married with two children, ages 18 and 3. She has run her own shop since 2003. She works from 8AM to 6PM each day and can earn a monthly profit of $70 from her sales.

Rahma is requesting a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with charcoal & firewood sales, coconuts sales, bites and juice sales.

loans.use: To buy more general store items for resale.

loans.name: Chhal

texts.en: Mrs. Chhal N. is the villager in Preak Ta Ong Ti Pie Village in Kandal Province. She is a mat maker and farmer. Her husband, Mr. Srun Kong, is a blacksmith and he helps his wife in the rice field. On the plantation, Mrs. Chhal N. faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to hire a laborer to plow her rice field. Thus, Mrs. Chhal N. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose, and she would use part of the loan to buy rice seeds to cultivate. Mrs. Chhal N. is 44 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in school. Mrs. Chhal N. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow her rice field and rice seeds to cultivate.

loans.name: Naov

texts.en: Mrs. Naov R. is a fruit "middleman" in Phlov Trei Village in Kandal Province. She now buys mango fruit to resell. She is a 55-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is a boat transporter who moves passengers across a river for an income. The younger one is attending the local school. Mrs. Naov R.'s family has only two businesses which can make a small income and savings. Mrs. Naov R. now wants to build a new house for her family; thus, she decided to ask for a loan in order to achieve this goal.

loans.use: To build a new house for her family.

loans.name: Yoem

texts.en: Mrs. Yoem S. lives in Boeng Krum Kraom Village in Kandal Province. She and her husband, Mr. Prum Bonh, are farmers. Aside from this business, Mr. Prum Bonh is rice wine maker and pig breeder in the local village. Since his business activities are going well, he wants to expand them. So Mrs. Yoem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets for $250, and she would use the other part of the loan to purchase more rice to make wine. Mrs. Yoem S. is 39 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is a farmer while other two are employed in a garment factory. The other two are attending school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and more rice to make rice wine.

loans.name: Njuma's General Store Group

texts.en:
NJ., 20, is married with a one-year-old child. She has been a shop owner since 2007. She works from 6AM to 10PM daily and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

NJ. is requesting a loan to buy more inventory items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with charcoal & banana sales, firewood sales, chips sales and shop ownership.

loans.use: To buy more inventory items for resale.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en: Tatu is 28-years-old, is married with two children, ages 7 and 2. Since 2007, she has owned a small charcoal store. She works from 6AM to 6PM each day and can earn a monthly profit of about $550 from her sales. Tatu  would like a loan to buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Khoeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Khoeurn P. and her husband, Mr. Hong Sor, are fishermen in Thmey Village in Kandal Province. Aside from this business, Mrs. Khoeurn P. grows corn. In the fish business, Mrs. Khoeurn P. and her husband now cannot go to gather fish because their boat is too old. Thus, Mrs. Khoeurn P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat to start her business again, and she would use the rest of the loan to purchase a motor for the boat. Mrs. Khoeurn P. is 41 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another one is a fisherman. The remaining two are attending school. Mrs. Khoeurn P. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a new boat and a motor for it.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Mr. Sum S. is a villager in L'vea Sor Kandal Village in Kandal Province. He is a Khmer noodle maker and his wife, Mrs. Chhoem Sophy, is a Khmer noodle seller. Mr. Sum S. now faces a problem because his noodle machine is too old and it cannot make a good Khmer noodles for his customers. Thus, Mr. Sum S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase a new Khmer noodle machine for his business. Mr. Sum S. is 54 years old and the father of seven children, two of whom are electricians while two are employed in a garment factory. The remaining three are attending school. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To purchase a new Khmer noodle machine for his business.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Mnyonge Hamini Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is a 30-year-old married woman with three children, ages 2, 4 and 3. She also takes care of two other children, ages 6 and 8. She began selling food in 2004 and works from 8AM to 6PM each day. She can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Mwajuma has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. She is requesting a new loan to increase her food inventory. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, Subira, who has a tailoring and bite sales business.

loans.use: To buy more food for resale.

loans.name: Savorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Savorn H., 33, is a farmer and her husband is a motorcycle driver. They live in Trapeang Preah Commune in Pursat Province. Her husband travels far from home to work in Phnom Penh and always sends money home to help support the family. They have one child, who is in school.

As there has been a rise in motor taxi use in Phnom Penh, Mrs Savorn would like her husband to change his motorcycle for a new one so as to attract more customers. Thus, she is requesting a loan for her husband to purchase a new motorcycle. Mrs. Savorn, her husband and son are pictured.

loans.use: To change his motorcycle to attract customers

loans.name: Oeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Oeurn S. O. lives in Ank Doung Village in Kandal Province. She is a housewife and her husband, Mr. Say Suth, is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support his family. They have four children, one of whom is working in a garment factory and two are attending school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. Although the family members have different businesses, they still live in an old house with poor conditions. In order to improve Mrs. Oeurn S. O.'s living conditions, she decided to ask for a loan to build a new house for her household. Previously, Mrs. Oeurn S. O. had obtained a loan from Acleda Bank to buy fertilizers and rice seeds. She also has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to build a new house for her household.

loans.name: Rahila's Tailoring And Clothing Shop Group

texts.en:
Rahila is 30-years-old, married with two children, ages 8 and 2, and has owned a tailoring and clothing sales business since 2002. She works from 5AM to 10PM and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Rahila has taken out one successful loan to expand her business. Rahila now requests a loan to buy more tailoring items and clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with charcoal &firewood sales, bites sales,chicken sales, clothes and chips sales.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring items and clothes for resale.

loans.name: Porn

texts.en: This is the second time Mrs. Porn S. has taken out a loan to improve her living conditions. She is a farmer in Ampil Village in Kandal Province. She is a 57-year-old widow with two children who are working in a garment factory. Although the family members have different businesses, they still live in an old house and their house now needs to be repaired. Unfortunately, Mrs. Porn S. does not have enough money to fix it, so she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Previously, Mrs. Porn S. had obtained a loan from AMK to buy fertilizer and rice seeds for her fields.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Penh

texts.en: Mr. Penh P., 25, is a farmer in Angk Village in Kandal Province. His wife, Mrs. Kim Sina, owns a small grocery store in the local village. On the plantation, Mr. Penh P. now faces a problem because he does not have enough money to buy rice seed to cultivate on the field. Thus, Mr. Penh P. decided to ask for a loan, and he would use the rest of the loan to buy more fertilizer, especially pesticide to kill insects. Previously, Mr. Penh P. had obtained a loan from Thaneakea Phum (Cambodia), LTD, to buy fertilizer and seed for cultivating. He also fully paid it back.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer, especially pesticide to kill insects.

loans.name: Asante's Usawa Group

texts.en:
Asante is 35 years old. She is married with 4 children aged 11, 8, 6, and 1. She has been a soft drinks and clothes seller since 2003. Every day, she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about US$ 185 from her sales.

Asante now hopes for a loan to buy more soft drinks items (juice) and clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with cassava and fish sales, clothing sales, charcoal and firewood sales,chicken sales, and shop ownership.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks (juice) items  and clothes for her business

loans.name: Rasema

texts.en:
Rasema was born in 1955, and she is from Đurđevik, a suburb of the town ŽIvinice. Her husband is a pensioner and receives 385 KM monthly.

This is the second loan that Rasema has requested from Women to Women International. Rasema would like 1000 KM to buy more chickens to increase her poultry business. Rasema wants to earn more money for her household and fill her free time during the winter by fattening and selling chickens.

loans.use: To buy chickens to fatten and sell.

loans.name: Hayakuwa's Usawa Group

texts.en:
Hayakua is a widow with 2 children aged 18 and 6. She has sold charcoal and clothes (khanga) since 2003. She works every day from 6 am to 6 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Hayakua now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and khanga for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with owing a shop, selling perfume, clothes and shoe sales, and charcoal sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Džemila

texts.en:
Džemila is a 40 year old woman from the village of Šerići, near the town ŽIvinice. She is divorced, and she works in a coffee bar. Her monthly salary is 600 KM. Because her salary is not sufficient to support her family, Džemila also sells cosmetic products from home to make additional money. Džemila lives with her parents, and she has an eighteen year old daughter.

This is Džemila’s second loan from our foundation, and she is asking for 600 KM. Džemila intends to use the money to buy more cosmetic products to sell from home to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetic products to sell from home.

loans.name: Suada

texts.en: Suada is 38 years old and from the village of Šerići. She is married with two children. Her husband has a full time job and his salary amounts to 850 KM per month. Suada is asking for a second loan from Women to Women International in the amount of 600 KM in order to buy hay for their cow. As cold weather approaches, the cow needs a lot of hay in order to be able to produce milk and milk products during the winter season.

loans.use: To buy hay for her cow.

loans.name: Dragana

texts.en:
Dragana is a 31 year old woman from Srebrenica. She is married, and her husband works in a zinc factory. They have three children, and they are all attending primary school.

This is Dragana’s second loan, and she is asking for 1200 KM. She intends to use the money to buy fruit trees and prepare them for the winter. Dragana also plans to purchase plums to make an alcoholic beverage called "rakija," or plum brandy, to sell.

loans.use: To buy fruit trees and plums.

loans.name: Milka

texts.en: Milka was born in 1951, and she lives with her husband in Srebrenica. Milka sells used clothing when she has time to go to the market. She can earn about 300 KM per month. Milka intends to use her loan, in the amount of 1 200 KM, to buy more clothing to sell. Through her loan and improved clothing sales, Milka wants to increase her monthly income, because her husband’s salary is not enough for the whole family to live on.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell at the market.

loans.name: Senija

texts.en:
Senija is a 37 year old housewife who works in agriculture and crop husbandry. This is Senija’s second loan, and she is requesting 1 000 KM.

Senija plans to use her loan money to buy more vegetable seeds for her greenhouse. She would also like to purchase pesticide and compost to prepare her land for the winter. Thus far, her business selling vegetables during the winter has been successful, and she can earn up to 200 KM per month. She hopes to increase her income through this loan, and thinks that these purchases will help her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable seeds for her greenhouse.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Her loan will be used to expand her business.

loans.name: Mirnesa

texts.en:
Mirnesa has one child. She lives with her family in the village of Ba Igovci, near the town ŽIvinice. Her husband has a full-time construction job in Slovenija.

This is Mirnesa's first loan, and she will use the money to buy chickens. Her wish is to buy and sell poultry in order to make more money for her family as well as produce healthy meat for them to eat. Mirnesa will sell some chickens during the winter and use others in her household. Her wish is to sell chicken as much as she can in order to earn money and to save it for the spring when she will buy new chicken.

loans.use: To buy chickens to sell and eat during the winter.

loans.name: Azra

texts.en:
Azra lives in Ba Igovci, a small village near the town of ŽIvinice. She is 30 years old and works with her husband in agriculture. Her husband also has a full time job, so it is mostly Azra who spends time in the field. They have two children, aged four and six years old.

This is Azra’s first loan, and she is asking for 1,000 KM to buy compost and to pay the cleaning of her field. She wants to have their land prepared for crops in the spring in order to plant vegetables and crops and after some time to sell it and earn money,

loans.use: To buy compost and prepare her field for spring crops.

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Philomina A. has been selling cosmetics such as perfume, creams, and others since 2001. Philomina has received a primary education. She is divorced and has 6 children. She is responsible for paying fees to educate her children. Her loan will be used to buy more goods for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more goods for sale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena E. is single and has 1 child. She has received schooling through senior high. Philomena sells corn and onions at Siwdo, which she has done since 2003. Philomena uses her income to pay for her children's school fees. Philomena will use the loan to purchase more corn and onions. With the new profits from her expanded business, Philomena plans to buy a piece of land to put up a building for the family.

loans.use: Philomena will use the loan to purchase more corn, vegetable oil, salt, and onions.

loans.name: Yusra

texts.en:
Yusra is 20 years old. She is married. She has been selling shoes and clothes since March 2008. Every day, she works from 8 AM to 6 PM at her business and she can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

Yusra now hopes for a loan to buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mbarawa

texts.en:
Mbarawa is 33 years old. She is married and she has 3 children aged between 3 and 8 years old. She has been selling decorations since 2004. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 3 PM at her business and she can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Mbarawa now hopes for a loan to buy more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary K. is married and has no child. She has received schooling through the primary level. Mary sells groceries like canned products, vegetable oil, rice, and others at Siwdo, which she has done since 1998. Her husband is a commercial driver. Mary uses her income to assist her husband in building their family house. Mary will use the loan to purchase more groceries for her shop. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to reinvest and also use part to buy building materials for their house.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to purchase more groceries for her shop.

loans.name: Mwajuma's Kujikwaa Si Kuanguka Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma is 25 years old. She is divorced and she has 2 children aged 4 and 8 years old. She has been selling charcoal and snacks since 2005. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 3 PM at her business.

Mwajuma is requesting a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, Fatma and Asha, who have businesses dealing with charcoal and firewood sales, and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business

loans.name: Tumu

texts.en:
Tumu is 41 years old. She is married and she has 6 children aged between 5 and 24 years old. She has been selling cigarettes and porridge since 2003. Every day, she works from 9 AM to 5 PM at her business and she can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Tumu is now requesting for a loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Gifty H. has been selling groceries like canned products, vegetable oil, rice, sugar, milk, and others at Siwdo since 2000. Gifty has received a junior high education.
